content: The "Cost of Higher Education Review Act of 1997" establishes the National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education to address the significant increase in tuition costs at public colleges and universities. The Act highlights the rising concern about college affordability and the financial burden it places on American families. The National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education is composed of 7 members appointed by various leaders and the Secretary of Education. Each member must have expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, or higher education administration. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson to lead its efforts. The National Commission on the Cost of Higher Education consists of 7 members with expertise in higher education finance, Federal financial aid programs, education economics research, or higher education administration. The Commission elects a Chairman and Vice Chairperson. A majority of members constitute a quorum for business transactions, and appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. If not, designated officials may make the appointments. The Commission members can act on behalf of certain leaders, each member has one vote, vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers, and members do not receive additional pay or benefits. FUNCTIONS OF COMMISSION. The Commission will study and make recommendations on tuition increases, methods to reduce tuition, administrative costs, faculty workload and remuneration, construction and renovation of facilities, and modernization of technologies in colleges and universities. The Commission will study trends in construction, renovation, and modernization of collegiate facilities impacting tuition. It will also analyze the impact of financial aid, tuition discounting, and laws on tuition increases, and recommend ways to reduce mandates contributing to rising tuition costs. Additionally, the Commission will propose a mechanism for timely distribution of data on tuition trends and operating costs of higher education institutions. The Commission will study the impact of laws on tuition increases, recommend ways to reduce mandates contributing to rising costs, propose a mechanism for timely data distribution, and submit a final report to the President and Congress with findings and recommendations within 120 days of the first meeting. The Commission will submit a final report to the President and Congress with findings and recommendations within 120 days of the first meeting, including recommendations for administrative and legislative action adopted by a majority vote of the Commission members. SEC. 5. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, adopt rules and regulations, and request information from federal agencies for the purpose of carrying out the Act. The Commission, under the Freedom of Information Act, can request facilities, services, and personnel from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. Additionally, the Commission can use the United States mails and enter into contracts as provided in appropriation Acts. The Commission can use the United States mails and enter into contracts with State agencies, private firms, institutions, and individuals for research purposes. The Chairperson has the power to appoint staff members without following certain regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an Executive Director and additional staff without being bound by certain regulations, at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Commission is authorized to be appropriated up to $650,000 for expenses and will cease to exist 60 days after submitting its final report.
